questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is evaluated for discharge from the eyes. The discharge was initially serous, but it quickly turned into mucopurulent and then purulent. On examination, the eyes are bright red and swollen. What is the most likely causative agent here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Explanation:

The clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of ophthalmia neonatorum caused by Neisseria gonorrhea and it presents as an inflamed, red, and swollen conjunctiva with discharge that changes fast.

 



 

Definition

  • Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis is a mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge from one or both eyes in the first month of life.
  • Any discharge, even watery, from a baby’s eyes in the first week of life must be viewed under suspicion as tears are not secreted so early in life.






 

Aetiology of ophthalmia neonatorum

Mode of infection:

  • Before birth:
    • Very rare through infected liquor amnii
  • During birth:
    • From an infected birth canal
  • After birth:
    • During the first bath of a newborn
    • Soiled clothes
    • Fingers with infected lochia
 

Source of infection:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Presents between 2-5 days of birth
    • The discharge becomes mucopurulent and purulent quickly
    • Inflamed, bright red, swollen conjunctiva
    • Thick yellow pus and marked chemosis
    • Cornea seen at the bottom of a crater-like pit in severe cases
    • Bulbar conjunctiva & lids: dense infiltration, swollen and tense
    • Free flow of pus, serum, and often blood later
  • Chlamydia trachomatis: (Option A)
  • Transmitted at the time of delivery
  • Onset at 5-14 days after birth
  • Serotypes D to K are the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries
  • Characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies are seen
  • Less severe inflammation
  • Purulent discharge
  • Other causes:
    • Staphylococci
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Gram-negative coliforms
    • Herpes simplex virus
    • Chemical: silver nitrate solution previously used for prophylaxis immediately after birth (Option B): erythema, chemosis, lid edema, and discharge within the first 24 hours after birth.

 
 

Prophylaxis

  • Antenatal measures:
    • Treatment of genital infections and care of mother
    • Surveillance of pregnant women for STDs
  • Natal measures:
    • Aseptic, sterile precautions to be followed during deliveries
    • Clean the infant’s closed lids with sterile cotton soaked in normal saline and dried
  • Post-natal measures:
    • Povidone-iodine 2.5% solution
    • If the mother is under suspicion, 1% tetracycline or 0.5% erythromycin eye ointment is used in the baby immediately after birth and watched for a week.
    • Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IM or IV single dose for infants born to mothers with untreated gonococcal infection.
  • Crede’s method:
    • Old method using 1% silver nitrate applied to infants' eyes right after birth
    • It is not used now as it can cause chemical neonatal conjunctivitis.

Diagnosis

Treatment

Neisseria gonorrhoea

Ceftriaxone IM, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

Chemical

Wash eyes, erythromycin ointment, observe

Other bacteria

Neomycin-bacitracin ointment, gentamicin, or tobramycin drops

Herpes simplex virus

Acyclovir 3% eye ointment, systemic acyclovir (systemic involvement)

Chlamydia trachomatis

Erythromycin or chlortetracycline eye ointment, oral erythromycin (systemic infection)


 

Treponema pallidum (Option C):

  • Causes syphilis and rarely manifests in the conjunctiva as a primary chancre.
  • It usually presents with bilateral interstitial keratitis by the age of 5-15 years.
  • In the conjunctiva, it usually occurs as a less indurated chancre and is transmitted by contact with an infected oral lesion.
  • Regional lymph node enlargement, along with a chronic ulcer or gummatous ulcer of the conjunctiva, suggests the disease.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient with dry eyes undergoes several tests. Which finding best supports the diagnosis of dry eye syndrome?

choices.text: Tear film break-up time of 15 seconds

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Extensive Rose Bengal staining

 

Explanation:

Extensive Rose Bengal staining indicates significant damage to the corneal and conjunctival epithelium, which is a feature of dry eye.


 

Slit-lamp examination
  • Superficial corneal erosions
  • Inadequate tear lake volume
  • Early tear film break-up time
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Conjunctival surface irregularities
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction

Schirmer’s Test:
  • Schirmer’s test is used to diagnose aqueous deficiency dry eye disease.

Schirmer's Test 1

  • Measures both basal and reflex tear secretions
  • Uses Whatman-41 filter paper, kept in the lower fornix at the junction of lateral one-third and medial two-thirds.
  • After 5 minutes, wetting of the filter strip from the bent end is measured.
  • Normal value: >15 mm
  • 5-10 mm: Mild to moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS).
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS (Option B)

 

Schirmer's Test 2

  • Measures only basal secretion under anesthesia

 

Phenol Red Test
  • A modified Schirmer’s test using a cotton thread impregnated with phenol red dye.
  • The thread is placed in the lower fornix for 15 seconds.
  • Phenol dye changes from yellow to red depending on the pH of the tears.
  • Wet length: >20 mm: Normal.
  • <10 mm: Severe dry eye.
  • ≤19 mm as borderline dry eye.

Tear Film Break-Up Time (TBUT)
  • Tear film stained with sodium fluorescein 1% is observed under a slit lamp, and time is noted after the patient blinks.
  • The interval between the complete blink and the first appearance of a ‘dark’ dry spot on the cornea is recorded as TBUT.
  • It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears.
  • Normal: 15-35 seconds
  • < 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film. (Option A)

 

Rose Bengal or Lissamine Green

Stain devitalized, desiccated corneal and conjunctival epithelium red or green. (Option C)

Rose Bengal stain

Lissamine Green

Alcian Blue

Stains particulate matter in the tear film due to mucus

Tear film Osmolality

Increased in dry eye (Option D)

Tear to Lysozyme ratio

Between 0.9 and 0.6 indicates dry eye.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient diagnosed with dry eye syndrome asks about the typical features of the condition. Which of the following is not commonly associated with dry eye?

choices.text: Frothy tears along the lid margin
Punctate epithelial erosions on the cornea

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Follicles on the conjunctiva

 

Explanation:

Follicles on the conjunctiva are typically seen in viral or chlamydial infections, not in dry eye.

 

Etiology of Dry eye:

Symptoms:

  • Irritation
  • Foreign body (sandy) sensation
  • Eye dryness
  • Reduced vision
  • Itching
  • Nonspecific ocular discomfort

 

Signs:

  • Tear Film Signs:
    • Presence of stingy mucus and particulate matter
    • Reduced or absent marginal tear strip
    • Frothy tears along the lid margin indicate meibomian gland dysfunction (Option A)
    • Posterior Blepharitis (Meibomitis): Inflammation of meibomian glands.

 

  • Conjunctival Signs:
    • Lustreless and mildly congested conjunctiva
    • Conjunctival xerosis and keratinization may occur (Option C)
    • Positive Rose Bengal or Lissamine green staining
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Punctate epithelial erosions (Option B)
    • Filaments and mucus plaques
    • Loss of corneal luster
    • Lesions delineated by fluorescein, Rose Bengal, or Lissamine green staining

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presents with dry eyes and mouth. Rose bengal staining shows conjunctival damage, and tear analysis reveals a tear-to-lysozyme ratio of 0.1. Which tear film layer is primarily deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aqueous layer

 

Explanation:

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (Sjögren syndrome) is the most likely diagnosis due patient’s history of RA and the tear-to-lysozyme ratio of 0.1, dry eyes and mouth, and conjunctival damage shown by Rose Bengal staining, which indicates a deficiency in the aqueous layer of the tear film.

 

Tear Film Layer

Secreted By

Function

Defective in

Innermost Mucinous Layer

(Option A)

Goblet cells, crypts of Henle, Manz’s glands

Convert hydrophobic corneal surface into hydrophilic one

Vitamin A deficiency

Middle Aqueous Layer

(thickest layer) (Option B)

Lacrimal and accessory conjunctival glands (Krause, Wolfring/Ciaccio)
  • Contain tears
  • Also contains antibacterial substances like lysozyme, beta-lysin, and lactoferrin.

Sjogren’s syndrome

Outermost Lipid Layer

(thinnest layer)

(Option C)

Meibomian glands
  • Prevent overflow of tears.
  • Retard evaporation.
  • Lubricates the eyelids.
  • Contact lens wear
  • Meibomian gland defect

 

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (sjögren syndrome)

Definition

Condition caused by deficiency of the aqueous component of tears due to impaired lacrimal secretion.

Pathology

Lacrimal glands show fibrosis and lymphocytic infiltration.

Occurs in

Postmenopausal women are often associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Symptoms

  • Eye dryness
  • Irritative symptoms
  • Epithelial erosions or filaments on the corneal surface

Clinical Diagnosis

Damage to the corneal and conjunctival epithelium can be seen with Rose bengal staining.

Tear Composition

Typical tear to lysozyme ratio of 0.1.

 

Primary Sjögren syndrome = Keratoconjunctivitis sicca + Xerostomia (dryness of mouth)

Secondary Sjögren syndrome = Primary Sjögren syndrome + Autoimmune disease (like Rheumatoid arthritis)

 

All layers equally affected (Option D): In Sjögren syndrome, the primary issue is a deficiency in the aqueous layer, not an equal impact on all layers.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with extensive sun exposure has a yellowish, triangular patch on the nasal conjunctiva, as shown below. The lesion does not extend onto the cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pinguecula

 

Explanation:

A yellowish, triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus, typically in the elderly, associated with sun exposure and not extending onto the cornea, points towards the diagnosis of Pinguecula.

 

Pinguecula

Definition

A triangular patch on the conjunctiva appears yellow and resembles fat (pinguis).

Pathology

Caused by hyaline infiltration and elastotic degeneration of submucous tissue.

Etiology

Common in elderly people, particularly those exposed to strong sunlight, dust, and wind.

Clinical Feature
  • Bilateral
  • Usually stationary
  • Yellowish triangular patch near the limbus
  • Apex of the triangle is away from the cornea
  • Affects the nasal side first, followed by the temporal side

Image

Complication

  • Inflammation of pinguecula
  • Intraepithelial abscess formation
  • Rarely calcification

Treatment

  • Generally, it requires no treatment.
  • When inflamed, treated with topical steroids.
  • May be excised when cosmetically unaccepted.

 

Pterygium (Option A) is a triangular, vascularized growth extending onto the cornea, whereas the lesion described is a yellowish, triangular patch on the conjunctiva that does not encroach onto the cornea, fitting the description of pinguecula.

 

 

Dermoid (Option C) appears as a lenticular yellow tumor near the corneal margin and consists of epidermoid epithelium with sebaceous glands and hair, whereas the lesion described is a yellowish, triangular patch on the conjunctiva that does not involve the corneal margin or have these characteristics.

 

 

Malignant melanoma (Option D) typically occurs at the limbus, is usually pigmented, and can spread or metastasize, whereas the described lesion is a yellowish, triangular patch on the conjunctiva without these features or aggressive behavior.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male comes to the clinic with complaints of a small fleshy triangular mass in the eye. There is no history of pain or discharge. On examination, it is as in the image.



What is true about this lesion?

choices.text: It can be present in any quadrant of the eye
It is caused by thermochemical burn, trauma, and chronic inflammation
Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma

 

Explanation:

The above clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of pterygium.

 

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

Pseudopterygium
 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.



 
  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process
  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth.
 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons
  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by (Option C)
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn




 

Pathology

 

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

  
 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane
  


 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side (Option B)
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium
  • Non-progressive (Option A)
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.


 
  • A probe can be passed under the neck.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with difficulty seeing at night. Which of the following is not a cause of nyctalopia (night blindness)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Cone dystrophy

 

Explanation:

Cone dystrophy is primarily associated with day blindness (hemeralopia), which is the inability to see clearly in bright light due to poor light adaptation.

 

Nyctalopia/ Night Blindness is the inability to see in low-light conditions. It is attributed to interference with the functions of the retinal rods.

 

Causes of Nyctalopia:

  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Xerophthalmia
  • Pathological myopia (Option B)
  • Advanced stage of primary open-angle glaucoma
  • Peripheral cortical cataract
  • Diffuse choroidal dystrophy
  • Choroideremia (Option D)
  • Gyrate atrophy (Option A):
    • Due to a deficiency of the enzyme ornithine aminotransferase, plasma ornithine levels are elevated.
    • Characterized by progressive patches of atrophy of choroid and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
    • Management: Restriction of arginine (precursor amino acid for ornithine) in diet. Vitamin B6 supplementation lowers plasma ornithine levels.

  • Congenital Stationary Night Blindness (CSNB):
    • Inherited retinal disease that causes night blindness in childhood.
    • 4 types of CSNB
      • Fundus Albipunctatus: Small white dots scattered across the posterior pole, sparing the fovea.
      • Oguchi Disease: Gray-white metallic sheen that disappears after dark adaptation (Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon).
      • Riggs: Normal fundus
      • Schubert-Bornschein: Normal fundus

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with symptoms of night blindness and dry eyes. On examination, there are Bitot's spots on the temporal side of both eyes. The child’s guardian reports that the child has had a history of frequent respiratory infections. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen to prevent further ocular complications?

choices.text: 100,000 IU of vitamin A orally on diagnosis, next day, and after 2 weeks.
Vitamin A eye drops and 10,000 IU orally for 1 month.
200,000 IU of vitamin A orally on diagnosis, next day, and after 2 weeks.
Oral multivitamins with increased vitamin A-rich foods for 3 months.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally on diagnosis, next day, and after 2 weeks.

 

Explanation:

  • This is the recommended treatment for children aged 1 year and older with xerophthalmia.
  • The WHO advises administering 200,000 IU of vitamin A immediately, then repeating the dose on the following day and again 2 weeks later.
  • This regimen rapidly replenishes vitamin A stores, which is crucial for reversing ocular damage and preventing severe complications such as corneal ulceration and blindness.

Pathological Changes in Epithelium and Tear Film:

1. Alterations in Conjunctival Epithelium:

  • Loss of Mucin Secretion: Leads to tear film instability.
  • Epidermoid Metaplasia: Epithelium transforms into stratified squamous epithelium with granular, keratinized and horny layers.

2. Impact on Tear Film and Ocular Surface:

  • Increased Tear Film Breakup: Exposes ocular surface to dryness.
  • Appearance: Conjunctiva becomes dry and loses its lustre.

 

Management:

Vitamin A Supplementation: The cornerstone of treatment is high-dose vitamin A supplementation. Dosages vary by age and severity of the condition:
 

Population

Vitamin A Dose

Treatment regimen

Children (≥1 year)

200,000 IU orally on diagnosis

Day1, Day 2, and 2 weeks later (Option C)

Children (Infants under 12 months)

100,000 IU orally

Day1, Day 2, and 2 weeks later (Options A and B)

Adults (non-pregnant)

200,000 IU orally

200,000 IU orally on Day 1, Day 2, and after 2 weeks.

Pregnant Women

10,000 IU orally daily

Daily oral administration of 10,000 IU for 1 month

(due to the risk of teratogenicity, higher doses are avoided during pregnancy).

Lactating Women

200,000 IU orally

One dose of 200,000 IU orally

 

Symptomatic Relief:

Artificial Tears: Lubricate the ocular surface, Frequency adjustment (1 to 6 hourly)

Mucomimetic Agents: Mimic natural mucin to stabilize the tear film; Used alongside artificial tear

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy from a rural area has difficulty seeing at night. Upon examination, you notice the presence of triangular, dry-white spots on the bulbar conjunctiva in both eyes. Which of the following represents the correct diagnosis and grade of xerophthalmia based on the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bitot’s Spots (X1B)

 

Explanation:

Bitot's spots are characteristic of xerophthalmia and appear as triangular, dry-white lesions on the bulbar conjunctiva, a hallmark of grade X1B xerophthalmia.
 

Grade

Symptoms

Signs

Image

XN (Night Blindness)

Difficulty seeing in low light (night blindness).

Normal conjunctiva, early visual impairment in low light conditions.

Nyctalopia: The earliest sign of xerophthalmia

X1A (Conjunctival Xerosis)

Dry eyes, lusterless appearance.

Non-wettable, dry conjunctiva affecting the interpalpebral area, resembling "sandbanks".

X1B (Bitot’s Spots)

Mild irritation, possibly no symptoms.
  • Triangular, dry-white masses on the bulbar conjunctiva, usually bilateral and temporal.
  • Bitot's spot consists of keratinized epithelium.
  • Associated with Corynebacterium infection
  • More common on the temporal side

X2 (Corneal Xerosis)

Blurred vision, and eye dryness.

Punctate keratopathy, hazy cornea with granular and xerotic changes, beginning from the nasal quadrant.

X3 (Corneal Ulceration & Scarring)

Severe eye pain, and visual impairment.

Collagen necrosis leads to sharply demarcated corneal ulcers, corneal scarring, and opacity.

XF (Xerophthalmic Fundus)

Visual impairment, difficulty with central vision.

Whitish, seed-like, raised lesions scattered in the posterior pole of the retina near the optic disc.

 

(Night Blindness - XN): Night blindness does not present with the visible, triangular, dry spots seen on the conjunctiva. Night blindness occurs in dim light, with no obvious external eye changes. (Option A)

(Conjunctival Xerosis - X1A): Conjunctival xerosis presents as dry, lusterless conjunctiva (Option B)

(Corneal Xerosis - X2): Corneal xerosis affects the cornea, typically presenting with haziness and granular or xerotic changes in the cornea (Option D)

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with a history of atopic dermatitis and asthma. He complains of tearing, burning, itching sensation and blurry vision for the past week. On examination, his eyelids are thickened and swollen, with signs of meibomitis. Slit-lamp examination reveals anterior subcapsular cataracts. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient’s ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical dual-acting antihistamine/mast cell stabilizer

 

Explanation:

Topical dual-acting antihistamine/mast cell stabilizer is the first-line treatment for atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It addresses both histamine release and mast cell stabilization, helping control inflammation and allergic responses.

 

Atopic Keratoconjunctivitis

Patient demographics

Common in young adults, often associated with a family history of atopic conditions such as asthma, allergic rhinitis, or atopic dermatitis.

Prevalent during winter months.

Disease characteristics

Severe, chronic ocular surface disorder with a range of severity from mild to persistent inflammation and extends into adulthood.

Characteristic findings

Symptoms; Tearing, burning, itching, clear mucus discharge,

Blurry vision, photophobia, foreign body sensation

Shield cataract/Atopic cataract (anterior or posterior subcapsular)

Eyelid Changes:

  • Thickened, swollen eyelids (intermittent due to chronic inflammation).
  • Lichenified and woody eyelids leading to Cicatricial ectropion and lagophthalmos
  • Madarosis.
  • Meibomitis and blepharitis
  • Dennie Morgan folds: Skin folds under the eyes due to excessive rubbing.

  • Hertoghe's sign: Loss of the lateral third of the eyebrows

Treatment
  • First-line therapy: Topical dual-acting antihistamine/mast cell stabilizer
  • If there is no improvement in 2-3 weeks: A brief course of topical corticosteroids. (Option A)
  • For moderate-to-severe disease requiring frequent corticosteroids - Use topical cyclosporine (2%, compounded). (Option C)
  • Eyelid Dermatitis: Topical tacrolimus is preferred over corticosteroids.

 

Oral antihistamines (Option D) may help with systemic symptoms, but they are not as effective for treating ocular manifestations directly.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with itching, watering, and redness in both eyes. On examination, small round yellow nodules are observed near the limbus, and conjunctival congestion is noted. The child has a past h/o TB. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this condition?

choices.text: Type I hypersensitivity reaction caused by environmental allergens
Type IV hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous bacterial antigens
Type II hypersensitivity reaction triggered by viral infections
Autoimmune reaction against corneal epithelial cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type IV hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous bacterial antigens

 

Explanation:

  • The above presentation is a case of phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis primarily mediated by a delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity reaction triggered by bacterial proteins of Staphylococcus aureus or tuberculosis.The child's history of TB is significant, as TB antigens can trigger this hypersensitivity response, leading to the characteristic ocular findings.
  • The immune system reacts to these antigens, causing the formation of nodules (phlyctens) and subsequent inflammation around the limbus.
  • This explains the localized inflammatory response seen in this condition.

 

Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis

Cause

Allergic reactions to endogenous antigens are often linked to bacterial infections such as Staphylococcus aureus (M/C/C in Western countries) or tuberculosis(M/C/C in India).

 

Symptoms & signs
  • Watering, itching
  • Reflex blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Phlycten - Small, round, grayish, or yellowish nodules on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus.
  • Corneal involvement can lead to fascicular ulcers or ring ulcers.

Pathophysiology

Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

Common Complications

Corneal involvement: Ulcers form on the cornea, leading to potential scarring.

Associated Conditions

Long-standing mild infections like tonsillitis or adenoiditis, and in populations with a high prevalence of tuberculosis.

Treatment

Local therapy:

  • Corticosteroids: Drops/ointment to reduce inflammation. Address underlying cause (e.g., tuberculosis).
  • Antibiotics
  • Cycloplegics: Paralyze ciliary muscle, relieve pain, and prevent complications.
  • Dark Glasses/Eye Shade: For photophobia relief.

General therapy:

  • Oral tetracycline or doxycycline is used in recurrent cases linked to Staphylococcal blepharitis.

Supportive: Dark glasses or eye shade.

 

Type I hypersensitivity reaction caused by environmental allergens(Option A):

Type I hypersensitivity from environmental allergens, like pollen, causes rapid IgE-mediated allergic reactions.

 

Type II hypersensitivity reaction triggered by viral infections(Option C):

Type II hypersensitivity, seen in viral infections, involves antibody-mediated cell destruction, not related to phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Autoimmune reaction against corneal epithelial cells(Option D):

Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is an immune response to bacterial proteins, not an autoimmune attack on corneal epithelial cells

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of worsening bilateral eye redness, itching, and frequent lacrimation. On examination, hypertrophied, cobblestone-like papillae is seen on the palpebral conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis


Explanation:

  • Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis is the most likely diagnosis given the patient’s age, the characteristic findings of cobblestone-like papillae on the palpebral conjunctiva
  • It commonly affects young children and adolescents, presenting with symptoms such as itching, burning, and lacrimation, and often worsens during warm weather.
     

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis or Spring catarrh

It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance;dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots
  • Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
 
  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
 
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.
 

Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

 

Atopic Keratoconjunctivitis (Option A) presents as a severe ocular surface disorder associated with a history of atopic diseases. It is more chronic and typically affects older children and adults.

 

Bacterial Conjunctivitis (Option C) presents with purulent discharge and often includes a fever or systemic signs. The given presentation does not favor this diagnosis.

 

Chlamydial Conjunctivitis (Option D) often involves a history of sexual contact or transmission and typically affects older children and adults. It usually presents with severe symptoms and sometimes includes a discharge with lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the epithelium of the conjunctiva?

choices.text: The epithelium of the limbal conjunctiva is thinner than that of the fornices.
The conjunctival epithelium is lined by stratified non-keratinized epithelium.
The adenoid layer of the conjunctiva is present at birth and plays a role in neonatal immunity.
The dense fibrous layer is superficial to the adenoid layer and contains goblet cells.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The conjunctival epithelium is lined by stratified non-keratinized epithelium.

 

Explanation:

The conjunctival epithelium is composed of stratified non-keratinized epithelium.

 

Layers of Conjunctiva

Outer Epithelial Layer

Lined by stratified squamous epithelium. The epithelium gradually thickens from the fornices to the limbus(Option A), becoming stratified and nonkeratinized near the corneal margin, while the palpebral conjunctiva lining the eyelids remains thinner and nonkeratinized. It contains:

  • Goblet cells
  • Melanocytes
  • Langerhans cells

Adenoid Layer (or lymphoid layer)

It is located below the epithelium. This layer develops lymphoid tissue only after 3-4 months of age, which explains why newborns cannot produce a follicular conjunctival reaction.(Option C)

Dense Fibrous Layer

It is present deep in the adenoid layer, merging into the underlying tissues (lid or sclera). This layer contains the vessels and nerves of the conjunctiva.(Option D)

questions.text: A patient with characteristic features of trachoma is being evaluated. Which of the following would be the most appropriate systemic antibiotic to be used for the treatment of trachoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Azithromycin

 

Explanation:

Azithromycin stands out as the preferred systemic antibiotic or treatment of choice, given its effectiveness and convenient dosing regimen, particularly when taken orally either as a single dose or as part of a mass drug administration approach.

 

Investigations

  • Micro-immunofluorescence (micro-IF): Using pooled antigens; For routine diagnostic purposes
  • Culture of C. trachomatis: In irradiated McCoy cells; Expensive
  • Monoclonal antibody direct tests: IgA-IPA light microscopy tests are the best combination for diagnosis

Management

SAFE is a WHO-recommended combination of interventions to treat trachoma and prevent it from leading to blindness

  • Surgery for cicatricial entropion and trichiasis (Tertiary prevention)
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism (Secondary prevention)
  • Facial cleanliness to avoid infection (Primary prevention)
  • Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation (Primordial prevention)

Environmental improvement (Primordial prevention)
  • Water latrines and good water supply to reduce flies
  • Refuse dumps
  • Sprays to control flies
  • Animal pens away from houses
  • Health education

Facial cleanliness (Primary prevention)
  • Frequent face wash with clean water
  • Avoid common towels, handkerchiefs, Surma rods, etc

Antibiotics (Secondary prevention)

Community-based mass antibiotic therapy:

  • For areas with 10% or more prevalence of active trachoma (TF in children 1-9 yrs):
    • Azithromycin single oral dose 20 mg/kg to all community members OR
    • Tetracycline 1% eye ointment BD for 6 weeks for all pregnant women, children, and those with allergies to macrolides.
    • Continued till TF prevalence in 1-9yrs becomes <5%
  • 5% to 10% prevalence: Antibiotic therapy targeted in the family and close contact only
  • Less than 5% prevalence: Only patients are treated

Blanket therapy (Intermittent therapy):

  • Indication: >5% prevalence of severe and moderate trachoma in 1-9 yrs old.
  • Application of 1% tetracycline ointment to all children:
  • Twice daily (BD) for 5 consecutive days each month, for 6 months OR
  • Once daily (OD) for 10 consecutive days each month, for 6 months OR
  • For 60 consecutive days
  • Alternative antibiotic: Erythromycin

Surgery (Tertiary prevention)
  • Simple epilation
  • Repair
  • Bilamellar tarsal rotation

 

Erythromycin (Option A) or doxycycline (Option B) may be considered, although caution is warranted with tetracyclines in pregnancy, breastfeeding, and among children, and hence, it is not preferred over azithromycin.

 

Amoxicillin (Option C) is not recommended as it would need a longer duration of administration and follow-ups.

questions.text:
A patient presents with irritation of the eyes and foreign body sensation in the eyes. He is examined by the ophthalmologist, who observes the following in his upper eyelid.




According to the WHO classification, which grade is the disease here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) TS

Explanation:

The above scenario is of trachoma wherein the picture represents a linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis called Arlt’s line, seen in trachomatou scarring stage.

 

WHO Grading System of Trachoma:

WHO Classification of Trachoma (FISTO)

Stage

Description

Image

Management

TF:

Trachomatous Inflammation- Follicular (Option A)
  • The presence of five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Active stage of trachoma
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism
  • Topical:
    • Tetracycline 1% or
    • Erythromycin 1%
    • Sulfacetamide
  • Systemic:
    • Tetracycline or erythromycin orally
    • Doxycycline orally
    • Azithromycin single oral dose
  • Combined systemic and topical therapy:
    • For TI or when an associated genital infection is present
    • Tetracycline 1% or erythromycin 1% eye ointment
    • Azithromycin orally

TI: Trachamatous Inflammation- Intense

(Option B)

Pronounced inflammatory thickening of the tarsal conjunctiva that obscures more than half of the normal deep tarsal vessels.

TS: Trachamatous Scarring

  • Presence of scarring in tarsal conjunctiva
  • White, bands or sheets of fibrosis in tarsal conjunctiva
  • Concretions removed with a hypodermic needle
  • Conjunctival xerosis with artificial tears (lubricating drops)

TT: Trachamatous Trichiasis

At least one eyelash rub on eyeball or evidence of recent removal of inturned eyelashes.
  • Permanent lash removal:
    • Electrolysis
    • Cryolysis
    • Radiofrequency epilation
    • Bilamellar tarsal resection
  • Cicatricial entropion surgery

CO: Corneal Opacity (Option C)
  • Easily visible corneal opacity over the pupil
  • Part of the pupil margin is blurred when seen through the opacity as it is very dense corneal scarring
  • After treatment of other trachoma sequelae
  • Penetrating keratoplasty for significant corneal scarring
  • Keratoprosthesis for bilateral blind cases with extensive scarring and surface problems
  • Punctal occlusion and lateral tarsorrhaphy for coexistent eye surface problems

questions.text: An 8-year-old female is being evaluated for conjunctivitis. She gives a history of itching and mild foreign body sensation in the eyes, stickiness of the lids, and mucoid discharge from the eyes. On examination, there is conjunctival congestion. Which of the following signs would be seen in this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Herbert’s follicles

 

Explanation:

The above clinical scenario points to an active trachomatous infection, and Herbert’s follicles are present in the limbal area of the eye in the active stage of the disease.

 

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line (Option B)
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus (Option A):
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)
 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis (Option D): Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis (Option C) due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

Lacrimal apparatus sequelae:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis
  • Chronic dacryoadenitis

questions.text: A 28-year-old man develops sudden redness, Foreign body sensation and subconjunctival haemorrhage in both eyes after returning from a tropical region. His visual acuity is normal. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Coxsackievirus

 

Explanation:

Sudden redness, foreign body sensation and subconjunctival haemorrhage, especially after travel to a tropical region, are characteristic of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, caused by Coxsackievirus.

Viral Conjunctivitis:

 

  • Causes:
    • Adenovirus
    • Herpes simplex
    • Herpes zoster
    • Molluscum contagiosum
    • Poxvirus
    • Myxovirus
    • Paramyxovirus

Adenovirus Conjunctivitis

 

Epstein-Barr virus (Option A) – Causes mild conjunctivitis but not acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 



 

Herpetic Conjunctivitis

(Option C)

Hemorrhagic Conjunctivitis/ Apollo Conjunctivitis

(Option B)

Molluscum Contagiosum

(Option D)
  • Commonly caused by herpes simplex type 1.
  • Seen in young children infected by contagion carriers of the virus.
  • Corneal vesicles merge to form dendritic figures.
  • Treatment:
    • Topical lubricants
    • If corneal is involved: Acyclovir 3% or vidarabine 3% eye ointment or trifluorothymidine 1% drops 5 times a day.
  • Cause:
    • Coxsackievirus
    • Enterovirus 70
  • Occurs in the pandemic form of violent inflammatory conjunctivitis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Lacrimation
    • Photophobia
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Enlarged preauricular lymph nodes
    • Cornea is usually affected
  • Caused by poxvirus.
  • Small, white, umbilicated swelling, generally multiple.
  • Produces severe conjunctivitis and occasionally keratitis.
  • Treatment: Surgical excision.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with irritation and redness at both eye corners, foamy discharge, and skin maceration as shown below. He also has chronic nasal discharge. Which organism is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moraxella axenfeld

 

Explanation:

  • The presence of localized inflammation, redness, and foamy discharge confined to the angles of the eyes, along with skin maceration around these areas, points towards the diagnosis of angular conjunctivitis.
  • The most common cause is Moraxella axenfeld.

 

Angular Conjunctivitis

Type of chronic conjunctivitis characterized by mild inflammation confined to the conjunctiva and lid margins near the angles of the eyes, associated with maceration of the surrounding skin.

Causative Agent
  • Moraxella axenfeld is the most common cause, leading to the term "diplobacillary conjunctivitis" due to the bacilli being arranged end-to-end.
  • Rarely Staphylococci.

Source of Infection

Nasal Cavity

Mode of Transmission

Infection is transmitted from the nasal cavity to the eyes via contaminated fingers or handkerchiefs.

Pathology

The bacillus produces proteolytic enzymes that macerate the epithelium, resulting in mild chronic inflammation and eczematous changes in the skin around the eye angles.

Symptoms

  • Irritation
  • Burning sensation
  • Discomfort in the eyes

Signs

  • Hyperemia of the bulbar conjunctiva and lid margins near the angles
  • Excoriation of the skin around the angles
  • Foamy mucopurulent discharge at the angles

Image

Complications
  • Blepharitis
  • Shallow marginal catarrhal corneal ulceration

Treatment

  • Oxytetracycline (1%) eye ointment applied 2-3 times a day for 9-14 days.
  • Zinc lotion instilled during the day, and zinc oxide ointment at bedtime to inhibit the proteolytic enzyme and reduce maceration.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with the eye condition shown in the image. The child reports severe eye pain, redness, and eyelid swelling. Examination reveals an inflamed conjunctiva with thick, adherent membranes that bleed when removed. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corynebacterium diphtheria

 

Explanation:

  • Child symptoms like thick, adherent membranes that bleed upon removal, along with the image showing inflamed conjunctiva with adherent membrane, suggest the diagnosis of membranous conjunctivitis.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria is the most common cause of membranous conjunctivitis.

 

Aspect

Membranous Conjunctivitis

Pseudomembranous Conjunctivitis

Characteristics

  • True membranes grow into the conjunctival epithelium and are more adherent.
  • Removal of these membranes often results in significant bleeding.
  • More superficial, with no growth into conjunctival epithelium, and are less adherent than true membranes.
  • These can be removed with minimal bleeding.

Causes

  • Bacterial: Corynebacterium diphtheria.
  • Drug Reactions: Hypersensitivity reactions, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).
  • Chemical or thermal injury.
  • Infectious: Mild Corynebacterium diphtheria infection, Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option B ruled out), Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D ruled out), Staphylococcus aureus, adenovirus (Option A ruled out), COVID-19.
  • Inflammatory: Hypersensitivity reactions, foreign body reactions.
  • Ligneous Conjunctivitis

Image

Symptoms

  • Eye redness
  • Eyelid swelling
  • Watery discharge
  • Visual disturbances
  • Foreign body sensation

Signs

  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Chemosis
  • Eyelid edema
  • Corneal edema
  • Mucopurulent discharge

Management

  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Lubricants improve comfort and rehydrate the eye.
  • Membranes can dissolve on their own.
  • Peeling of pseudomembrane.
  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Removal of foreign bodies if present.
  • Washing the ocular surface to remove chemical irritants.

questions.text: A 7-year-old presents with severe eye pain, intense redness, and copious purulent discharge from his right eye. He also has significant lid swelling and tender preauricular lymphadenopathy. Gram stain of the purulent discharge reveals Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intramuscular Ceftriaxone

 

Explanation:

The presence of copious purulent discharge, tender preauricular lymphadenopathy, and Gram-negative intracellular diplococci strongly suggests gonococcal conjunctivitis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae also termed as acute blennorrhea/ acute purulent conjunctivitis/ hyperacute conjunctivitis, treated with single dose Ceftriaxone IM and oral Azithromycin or doxycycline (twice a day for 7 days).


 

Acute Mucopurulent Conjunctivitis:

  • M/c cause: Staphylococcus aureus
  • Symptoms:
    • Redness
    • Mucus discharge
    • Eyelids stick together, especially in the morning

  • Treatment: Topical Antibiotics:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., chloramphenicol, lomefloxacin, ofloxacin, ciprofloxacin) applied 4-6 times daily.
    • Antibiotic ointment for lid application to prevent sticking and manage discharge.

 

Acute Purulent Conjunctivitis/ Hyperacute conjunctivitis/ Acute blennorrhoea:

  • M/c cause: Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Symptoms:
    • Fiery red conjunctiva (‘pink eye’)
    • Severe pain
    • Lid swelling
    • Copious purulent discharge
    • Pus seen in the fornices and margin of the lid
    • Matting of lashes with dirty yellow crust
    • Coloured halos
    • Tender preauricular lymphadenopathy

  • Treatment: Systemic Antibiotics:
    • Single dose Ceftriaxone IM and oral Azithromycin or doxycycline (twice a day for 7 days)


 

Intravenous ampicillin (Option A) is not the first-line treatment for hyperacute conjunctivitis and is not commonly used.

 

Eye irrigation with saline (Option B) might provide temporary relief but does not address the underlying infection. Systemic antibiotics are needed to prevent complications.

 

Topical antibiotic drops (Option D) are generally insufficient for treating hyperacute conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae; systemic antibiotics are required.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of soft contact lens use for the past 8 months presents with bilateral itching, redness, and watery discharge. Examination shows large, polygonal papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

A history of prolonged soft contact lens use, along with symptoms like bilateral itching, redness, watery discharge, and the presence of large, polygonal papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, points towards a diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

 

Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis

Definition

Specific allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.

Etiology

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lenses
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prostheses

Underlying Mechanism

Hypersensitivity reactions (types I and IV)

Symptoms

  • Itching
  • Watering
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Occasionally blurred vision

Signs

  • Conjunctival congestion predominantly in the upper palpebral region
  • Large polygonal papillae on superior tarsal conjunctiva
  • Macropapillae (0.3-1.0 mm) and giant papillae (1-2 mm)

Management

  • Discontinue soft contact lenses, remove offending sutures, clean and polish ocular prosthesis; replace with biocompatible material (e.g., Biocoat).
  • Ancillary therapy: Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium, olopatadine) along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops, and decongestants.

Image

papillary conjunctivitis" data-author="Mpopi Lenake & Nagib du Toit" data-hash="4244" data-license="CC BY-NC-ND 4.0" data-source="https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/figure/10.1080/20786190.2014.977017?scroll=top&needAccess=true" data-tags="March2025" height="353" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/xqINweIHQcEvsqTa1n2k1743136949.png" width="500" />


 

Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (Option A) is characterized by seasonal symptoms, cobblestone-like papillae, limbal thickening with Horner-Trantas dots, and potential corneal involvement, unlike giant papillary conjunctivitis, which typically presents with large papillae associated with contact lens use.

 

Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis (Option C) shows small nodules near the limbus with localized congestion, not large papillae on the tarsal conjunctiva, as seen in giant papillary conjunctivitis.

 

Papillary Conjunctivitis (Option D) is a broad term and lacks the specificity of the large, polygonal papillae and pronounced symptoms seen in Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis, which is linked to contact lens use.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman reports bilateral itching, redness, and watery discharge that worsens in spring. Examination revealed mild conjunctival congestion with small papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Allergic Conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

  • Given the seasonal pattern of symptoms, bilateral itching, watery discharge, mild conjunctival congestion, and the presence of small papillae point toward the diagnosis of allergic conjunctivitis.

 

Conjunctival inflammatory reactions can be in the form of:

Follicles

Papillae

Granuloma

  • Yellowish-white, round elevations, 1-2 mm in diameter, due to lymphocyte aggregations in the subepithelial adenoid layer.
  • Conjunctiva of newborns cannot produce follicles until 2-3 months of age.
  • Hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.
  • Fleshy, sessile, or pedunculated lesions with inflammatory tissue.
  • May or may not be truly granulomatous.
  • Resulting from chronic local irritation, such as foreign bodies.

 

Viral Conjunctivitis (Option A) typically presents with watery discharge and moderate conjunctival congestion.

  • It is often associated with follicles rather than papillae, and a seasonal pattern is less likely than that of allergic conjunctivitis.

 

Bacterial Conjunctivitis (Option C) is characterized by purulent discharge and marked conjunctival congestion.

  • While bacterial conjunctivitis can sometimes present with papillae, these are not usually as prominent or marked as those in allergic conjunctivitis.

 

Chlamydial Conjunctivitis (Option D) typically presents with mucopurulent discharge and moderate conjunctival congestion.

  • It is often associated with follicles, and papillae may or may not be present.
  • The lack of prominent papillae and specific seasonal patterns make it less likely than allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with redness, mild swelling, and foreign body sensation in the right eye for 2 days. On examination, no visual impairment is noted, and a diagnosis of acute conjunctivitis is made. Which of the following is not a common sign of conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)

 

Explanation:

Ciliary congestion, also known as ciliary injection, is not a sign of conjunctivitis. It refers to deep, radial vessel congestion around the limbus, usually associated with intraocular conditions like iritis, keratitis, or acute glaucoma. The vessels here are part of the deeper structure of the eye, unlike the superficial vessels involved in conjunctivitis.

 

Symptoms and Signs of Conjunctivitis:

  • Hyperemia or redness of the conjunctiva (Option B)
  • Pain
  • Photophobia (rare, associated corneal involvement or iritis can be present)
  • Blepharospasm
  • Discharge (prominent feature)
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage (Option C)
  • Chemosis or conjunctival edema (Option A)
  • Inflammatory reactions: Follicles (localized aggregation of lymphocytes), papillae (hyperplasia of the normal vascular system), granulomas
  • Pseudomembranes/True membranes

 

Feature

Conjunctival Congestion

Ciliary Congestion

Location of Congestion

Confined to the conjunctiva, often more marked in the fornices.

Involves the area around the corneal margin, known as the limbal region.

On moving conjunctiva

Congested vessels also move

Congested vessels do not move

Common Causes

Bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, viral conjunctivitis

Acute iridocyclitis, acute glaucoma, keratitis, corneal ulcer.

Image

questions.text: Which of the following glands are primarily responsible for secreting mucus to maintain ocular surface moisture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Goblet cells

 

Explanation:

  • Goblett cells are located in conjunctival epithelium; secrete mucin, which forms the mucous layer of the tear film, essential for ocular surface moisture and stability.

  • Goblet Cells are unicellular mucous-secreting glands located within the epithelium of the conjunctiva. They produce mucus and maintain the ocular surface's moisture.

A) Glands of Krause → Accessory lacrimal glands → secrete aqueous component of tears, not mucus.

C) Glands of Wolfring → Another type of accessory lacrimal gland → also produce aqueous secretions.

D) Glands of Moll → Modified sweat glands at lid margin → not mucus-secreting.
